Luis *, M.I. Burguete, B. Altava Laboratorio de Quica Orgica, Departamento de Ciencias Experimentales, ES. TC.E., University Jaume I, E-12080 Castell, Spain Received XX; Accepted XX Abstract The preparation of functionalized polystyrene-divinylbenzene resins containing functional groups bonded to the polymeric matrix by a long alkyl chain has been accomplished in a two-step procedure from unfunctionalized resins and the acid chloride of a monoalkyl ester of an alkanedioic acid. The procedure is useful for the preparation of spacer-modified polymers of variable crosslinking degrees, including highly crosslinked macroreticular resins such as XAD-4. The high mobility of the chains is revealed by the easy analysis of the polymers by gel-phase 13C-NMR spectroscopy. Keywords: Polymer-supported reagents; Polystyrene-divinylbenzene; Spacer-modified polystyrene 1. Introduction The most common starting materials for the preparation of polymer-supported reagents or catalysts continue to be chloromethylated polystyrene resins [1-3]. The easy chloromethylation of polystyrene copolymers [4-6] as well as the high reactivity of the resulting benzylic positions allow the simple introduction of a large number of functional groups and explain the widespread use of these polymers [7]. However, two main disadvantages are- often found in the use of chloromethylated resins. First of all, the formation of benzylic bonds that can be unstable under the conditions needed for further transformations and can give place to undesired * Corresponding author. 1381-5148/95/$09.50 1995 Elsevier Science B.V All rights reserved. SSDI1381-5148(95)00008-9 reactions [8,9]. On the other hand, direct attachment to the polymeric backbone through a methylene spacer reduces the mobility of the functional group introduced and, in some cases, makes their accessibility to reagents, substrates and solvents difficult. This drawback is further increased if we consider that chloromethylation of polystyrene or polystyrene-divinylbenzene resins is often accompanied by additional crosslinking of the polymer chains [10]. This situation can lead to a decrease in the activity of polymerbound reagents and catalysts when compared with their soluble counterparts. In some instances, a clear improvement of the activity of polymer-supported species has been obtained when the active site is separated from the polymeric backbone through an appropriated spacer chain, (see, for instance, Refs. [11-19]). 76 S. V Luis et al. /Reactive & Functional Polymers 26 (1995) 75-83 Accordingly, much effort has been devoted to the preparation of resins functionalized through different spacers [11-29]. Functionalization of polystyrene polymers through dimethylene spacers has been studied in detail [13,26,27] and a number of resins containing longer spacers have been described for different applications. In general, spacers longer than dimethylene contain additional functional groups (ester, amide, ether, amino, etc.) which may interfere for some catalytic applications. From the different approaches to the preparation of polymers modified through long aliphatic spacers [15,17,18,27], the most general and wider application seems to be the one devised by Tomoi via alkylation of polystyrene resins with o)-bromoalkenes in the presence of trifluoromethanesulfonic acid. However, the method is limited to the preparation of spacer-modified polymers containing low degrees (0-4%) of crosslinking. Here we report on a different approach to prepare such spacer-modified resins from readily available starting materials. This novel method is applicable to microreticular as well as to macroreticular polymers. 2. Results and discussion The general procedure developed for the preparation of functionalized polymers containing long aliphatic spacers is outlined in Scheme 1. The key step for this procedure is the preparation of polymeric keto ester 2. Functionalization of crosslinked polystyrenes to afford intermediate 2 could be accomplished in excellent yields by reaction with the chloride of a monoalkyl ester of an alkanedioic acid in CSZ in the presence of AIC13, in conditions similar to those described for related acylation reactions [22,30,31]. After thorough washing to free the polymer from any residual amount of AIC13 [31] the polymers showed in the IR spectra the presence of two distinct carbonyl bands at 1678 and 1733 cm-1 corresponding to the keto and the ester functional groups. The degree of functionalization of the resulting resins was determined by conversion into the corresponding polymeric oximes 4 or thioketals 5, and elemental analysis for nitrogen or sulfur. Both reactions were easily monitored through the disappearance of the C=O carbonyl band corresponding to the keto group. Thioketal formation seems to be a more reliable procedure, as results derived from oxime derivatives were affected by conditions used for the derivatization reaction. Thus, for instance, when derivatization was carried out in a mixture of EtOH, dioxane and water in the presence of NaOH [31], oxime formation was accompanied by reaction of the ester group to give a hydroxamic acid [32] as observed in the IR by a decrease in the intensity of the C=O ester band and the appearance of a novel band at 1568 cm-1 for the salt of the hydroxamic acid. However, when pyridine was used as the base and the solvent [33] results were, in general, in good agreement with those found through thioketal formation. Quantitative transformation of 2 into 5 was accomplished by reaction of 2 with an excess of ethanedithiol in the presence of BF3 as the catalyst. Results obtained for functionalization of polystyrene resins of variable crosslinking degrees, according to Scheme 1, to give polymers 2 are summarized in Table 1. It has to be noted that a loading of ca. 2 mEq/g represents that 31% of the weight of polymer 2 corresponds to the weight of the functional group introduced when the monoester of the adipic acid is used. An excess of catalyst over the alkanedioic acid derivative seems to be needed to obtain good yields for the anchoring of the keto ester moiety. For microreticular resins containing 1 or 2% DV13 as well as for the XE-305 resin, reaction was essentially complete after stirring at room temperature for a period of ca. 24 h. After this time, more than 90% of the reagent added had been bound to the resins. In general, once the acid chloride is consumed, an increase in the reaction time is not advisable, as a slow crosslinking process can take place, in the presence of the excess of catalyst, by an additional Friedel-Crafts reaction of the ester groups of the spacers. For macroreticular resins such as XAD-2 and XAD-4 [34] functionalization was limited to loadings be- 78 S. V Luis et al. /Reactive & Functional Polymers 26 (1995) 75-83 low 1 mEq/g, but degrees of functionalization in the range of 0.5-1.0 mEq/g were easily achieved in the same conditions used for microreticular polymers. This limitation is usually found in the work with highly crosslinked polystyrenes. In both cases, degrees of functionalization could be controlled in a simple way by the amount of acid chloride or catalyst added and reaction time. When adipic acid reagent was changed for the acid chloride derived from the monomethyl ester of azelaic acid very similar results were obtained, but a slight decrease in the functionalization of the resins was usually observed. Transformation of polymer-bound keto esters 2 into resins of general structure 3 requires conversion of the keto functionality into a methylene group. Different reagents have been described to carry out such a transformation, but many of them are used under very drastic conditions which are non-compatible with the polymeric nature of 2. In our hands, best results were obtained when reduction of the keto group to methylene was accomplished through initial formation of tosylhydrazone 6. This transformation was quantitatively achieved by reaction of 2 with an excess of tosylhydrazine in EtOH [35,36]. The IR spectra of the resulting polymers 6 showed the presence of a unique carbonyl band corresponding to the ester fragment. Both LiAlH4 and catecholborane have been described for the conversion of tosylhydrazones to methylene groups. When LLAAH4 in THF was used [37], IR spectra of the resulting resins showed the absence of the carbonyl band characteristic of the ester group, revealing transformation of 6 into polymer-supported alcohol 8. In general, it was observed that difficulties to obtain complete reduction of functional groups in 6 increase with functionalization degrees of starting polymers 2. Satisfactory gel-phase 13 C-NMR spectra were usually obtained from samples swollen in CDC13 and made homogeneous by ultrasonical stirring, even with the use of a 5-mm probe at 50.5 MHz. All spectra showed the signals characteristic of the polymeric backbone centered at 40-45, 125-130 and 145 ppm. In summary, functionalization of polystyrene resins through long aliphatic spacers can be easily accomplished in a two-step procedure from unfunctionalized polystyrenes and the acid chloride derived from the monoalkyl ester of an alkanedioic acid. Monoalkyl esters of alkanedioic acids are easily obtained [43] and some of them are commercially available. Functionalization degrees can be controlled by an appropriate selection of the amount of reagent, catalyst and reaction times. An important feature of the method is that it can be used for microreticular as well as macroreticular resins. If long reaction times and high temperatures are avoided, no appreciable additional crosslinking of the resins is observed. Gel phase 13C-NMR data suggest a Scheme 5. 81 O KOH P methylglyrnV~ret u x OH 12 TsCI R2NH O P NRz 14 high mobility for the spacer chains introduced by this method. Modification of the functional groups introduced in the chain by standard procedures allows an efficient incorporation of a variety of functionalities. 3. Experimental Commercial polystyrene-divinylbenzene copolymers were purchased from Fluka and washed and vacuum dried to constant weight before use. IR spectra of KBr pellets of polymers were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer 2000 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Gel-phase 13C-NMR spectra of solvent-swollen polymers were obtained in CDC13 on a Varian Gemini 200 instrument at 50.289 MHz equipped with a 5-mm broadband probe. NMR samples were made homogeneous by stirring on an ultrasonic bath. Quantitative elemental analyses were performed in duplicate on a Carlo Erba EA1108 CHNS-O instrument. 3.1. General procedure forpreparation of polymer-supported keto esters 2 In a typical procedure, to a stirred suspension of polystyrene crosslinked with 1% of divinylbenzene (10 g, 0.10 mol styryl residues) and AIC13 (11 g, 0.083 mol) in CSz (150 ml) was added dropwise a solution of the acid chloride of the 82 S. V Luis et al. /Reactive & Functional Polymers 26 (1995) 75-83 monoethyl ester of adipic acid (5 g, 0.029 mol). After stirring at room temperature for 24 h, the polymer was filtered and washed with 0.5 M HCl/dioxane (5 : 2) (3 x), H20/dioxane (4 :1) (3 x ), H20/dioxane (2 :1) (3 x ), H20/acetone/ dioxane (3 :1:1) (3 x ), H20/acetone/dioxane (1:3:1) (3x), acetone/dioxane (1:1) (3x), MeOH/acetone/dioxane (1:1:1) (3 x), MeOH/ dioxane (2 :1) (3 x), MeOH/dioxane (1 :1) (3 x), dioxane/Et20 (2:1) (3x), dioxane/Et20 (1:1) (3 x) and Et20 and finally vacuum dried to constant weight to give resin 2 (n = 2, R=Et). IR (KBr): 1733 and 1678 cm-1. For analytical purposes, 50 mg of polymer 2 was suspended in 10 ml of dry CH202 containing 0.2 ml of ethanedithiol and 0.2 ml of BF3-Et20 complex, and the mixture was stirred under an argon atmosphere at room temperature for 24 h. The resin was filtered and washed with CH202 (3 x), THF (3 x), THF/MeOH (2 :1) (3 x), THF/ MeOH (1:1) (3 x), MeOH (3 x), CH2Cl2 (3 x) and acetone (3 x) and vacuum dried to afford thioketal 5 (n = 2, R=Et). The preparation of functionalized polystyrene-divinylbenzene resins containing functional groups bonded to the polymeric matrix by a long alkyl chain has been accomplished in a two-step procedure from unfunctionalized resins and the acid chloride of a monoalkyl ester of an alkanedioic acid. The procedure is useful for the preparation of spacer-modified polymers of variable crosslinking degrees, including highly crosslinked macroreticular resins such as XAD-4. The high mobility of the chains is revealed by the easy analysis of the polymers by gel-phase 13C-NMR spectroscopy.
